titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: Any society, however organized, which accepts the teaching of Christ, & looks to Him for life & inspiration, is entitled to be called part of the Catholic Church
Storr. Development of Eng: Theol: p. 264.
has not burnt up everything when a Canon of Winchester & Archbishop's chaplain can write thus.
To the 'Lay communicant', from whom yesterday I received a very insulting letter, I sent a copy of "Ecclesiastica" with the Dean's compliments.

body.p: I celebrated at 8 a.m. There were but 14 comts including Olive & myself. Knowling preached an excellent sermon at Mattins: Olive & I walked with Logic round the wood before lunch.

p.hi: 1914, I entertained at supper the Clerk of the Works & his workmen the Gardeners, the Vergers & Sub–Vergers, the Bell–ringers, & the Porter. Knowling came as Canon–in–Residence, & Wilson & Bayley. The party invited numbered 34, & all appeared save two, who were hindered by imposition. After supper, I made a very brief speech, & then we adjourned to the Billiard Room.

body.p: On Tuesday, the 13th Jany, Caröe arrived, and after seeing the Cathedral with Macartney, he left on Wednesday, the 14th.

On Wednesday, the 14th Jany, I went to Hartlepool, & addressed a meeting organized by the C.E.M.S. in the Town Hall. Colonel Burdon presided, & I spoke for 3/4 of an hour on "The Mission of the Church of England". There were about 200 men present. I motored back to the Deanery in about 65 minutes.

p.hi: , the German Ambassador Prince Lichnowski came to Durham. I shewed him over the Deanery, Cathedral, & Castle.
